Award.AwardTitle: Tropospheric Influences on Stratospheric Low-frequency Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will contribute to improved predictions of future variations of climate. This will allow society to prepare better for natural variations and anthropogenic changes of future climate. The project will also support the training of two graduate students, and the results from this research will be incorporated into graduate level teaching. Finally, this project will provide support for local, national, and international outreach activities on climate change

It is now well established that conditions in the stratosphere influence weather and climate in the troposphere. The stratospheric polar vortex and variations in its strength play a key role for this influence. The polar vortex is a westerly wind system that develops during polar night over the Arctic stratosphere. Polar vortex variations are related to stratospheric sudden warmings (SSW), but there may be other non-SSW related causes as well.

This project will contribute to new and improved insight into the dynamical coupling between stratosphere and troposphere, the mechanisms involved in it, and how to simulate it with models. The project will also contribute to improved understanding of deficencies present in climate models and the impact this has on future predictions of the global climate. Potentially, this will improve the ability to make decadal predictions, and it may have implications for the determination and attribution of decadal trends. It may also help to obtain a more precise picture of future changes in the occurrence rates of SSWs, make more realistic predictions of the recovery of ozone, and increase the certainty of climate change projections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background:Research over the past two decades has shown that the troposphere (0-10 km) and the stratosphere (10-50 km) influence each other, and that it is important to simulate this influence with numerical models to improve forecasting of weather and predictions of climate. The influence between stratosphere and troposphere is closely related to the stratospheric polar vortex, a strong wind system over the northern hemisphere high latitudes during winter. Variations in the strength of the polar vortex are related to weather and climate at the surface, and in some rare cases, these variations are so strong that the normal direction of the vortex reverses. Much of the influence of the stratosphere on the troposphere can be explained in terms of such extreme events, and for model simulations it is important to understand the factors that are behind such variations. For example, many modern climate models do not simulate very realistically the strength of the vortex and/or the observed occurrence frequency of the extreme circulation events, creating additional unwanted errors in the simulations. 

Goals:The main goal of this research was to better understand the tropospheric and stratospheric factors that control the strength of the polar vortex and the frequency of extreme stratospheric circulation events, and also to understand how variations in the strength of the polar vortex affect other components of climate, like sea ice and the oceans.

Outcomes: Overall, this project contributed to new and improved insight into how the stratosphere and the troposphere influence each other and how to better simulate this influence with numerical models. For example, we now understand the reasons for the specific seasonal timing of extreme stratospheric circulation events, enabling us to better judge whether a model simulation is accurate or not (see Figure). We also found that he simulation of the stratosphere is a good indicator for the overall performance of a model, and that the stratospheric circulation depends on many subtleties in a model, like certain conditions at the surface. Further, our research showed that variations in the stratospheric circulation can impact the distribution of Arctic sea ice and influence the ocean circulation of the North Atlantic. We now also better understand why modern climate models have problems in properly simulating the stratosphere. This knowledge contributes to improved understanding for the deficiencies present in climate models. It may also help to obtain a more precise picture of future changes in the occurrence rates of extreme stratospheric circulation events, make more realistic predictions of the recovery of stratospheric ozone, and increase the certainty of climate change projections.

Broader impacts:Potentially, knowledge gained in this project will lead to improved models and better predictions of weather and climate, helping society to prepare better for natural variations and anthropogenic changes of climate. The project also supported the training of four graduate students and two undergraduate students, and it provided support for local, national, and international outreach activities.
